column1: There is some common terminology for angles
column2: whose measure is always non-negative (see § Signed angles):

column1: An angle equal to 0° or not turned is called a zero angle.
An angle smaller than a right angle (less than 90°) is called an acute angle (""acute"" meaning ""sharp"").
An angle equal to 1/4 turn (90° or π/2 radians) is called a right angle. Two lines that form a right angle are said to be normal
An angle larger than a right angle and smaller than a straight angle (between 90° and 180°) is called an obtuse angle (""obtuse"" meaning ""blunt"").
An angle equal to 1/2 turn (180° or π radians) is called a straight angle.
An angle larger than a straight angle but less than 1 turn (between 180° and 360°) is called a reflex angle.
An angle equal to 1 turn (360° or 2π radians) is called a full angle
An angle that is not a multiple of a right angle is called an oblique angle.The names
column3: and measuring units are shown in the table below:

column2: angles have been measured in various units. These are known as angular units

It is frequently helpful to impose a convention that allows positive and negative angular values to represent orientations and/or rotations in opposite directions or ""sense"" relative to some reference.
In a two-dimensional Cartesian coordinate system
column2: an angle is typically defined by its two sides
column3: with its vertex at the origin. The initial side is on the positive x-axis
column4: while the other side or terminal side is defined by the measure from the initial side in radians
column5: degrees
column6: or turns
column7: with positive angles representing rotations toward the positive y-axis and negative angles representing rotations toward the negative y-axis.  When Cartesian coordinates are represented by standard position
column8: defined by the x-axis rightward and the y-axis upward

column2: an angle of −θ is effectively equivalent to an angle of ""one full turn minus θ"". For example
column3: an orientation represented as −45° is effectively equal to an orientation defined as 360° − 45° or 315°.  Although the final position is the same
column4: a physical rotation (movement) of −45° is not the same as a rotation of 315° (for example
column5: the rotation of a person holding a broom resting on a dusty floor would leave visually different traces of swept regions on the floor).

column3: so the direction of positive and negative angles must be defined in terms of an orientation
column4: which is typically determined by a normal vector passing through the angle's vertex and perpendicular to the plane in which the rays of the angle lie.

column2: bearings or azimuth are measured relative to north.  By convention
column4: bearing angles are positive clockwise
column5: so a bearing of 45° corresponds to a north-east orientation. Negative bearings are not used in navigation
column6: so a north-west orientation corresponds to a bearing of 315°.

column4: where the references vary according to the particular system. Astronomers measure the angular separation of two stars by imagining two lines through the center of the Earth

column1: Astronomers also measure objects' apparent size as an angular diameter. For example
column2: the full moon has an angular diameter of approximately 0.5° when viewed from Earth. One could say
column3: ""The Moon's diameter subtends an angle of half a degree."" The small-angle formula can convert such an angular measurement into a distance/size ratio.

column1: 0.5° is the approximate diameter of the Sun and of the Moon as viewed from Earth.

10° is the approximate width of a closed fist at arm's length.
20° is the approximate width of a handspan at arm's length.These measurements depend on the individual subject

column2: a polygon () is a plane figure made up of line segments connected to form a closed polygonal chain.

column1: The segments of a closed polygonal chain are called its edges or sides. The points where two edges meet are the polygon's vertices or corners. An n-gon is a polygon with n sides; for example
A simple polygon is one which does not intersect itself. More precisely
column2: the only allowed intersections among the line segments that make up the polygon are the shared endpoints of consecutive segments in the polygonal chain. A simple polygon is the boundary of a region of the plane that is called a solid polygon. The interior of a solid polygon is its body
column3: also known as a polygonal region or polygonal area. In contexts where one is concerned only with simple and solid polygons
column4: a polygon may refer only to a simple polygon or to a solid polygon.

column1: A polygonal chain may cross over itself
column2: creating star polygons and other self-intersecting polygons. Some sources also consider closed polygonal chains in Euclidean space to be a type of polygon (a skew polygon)
column3: even when the chain does not lie in a single plane.

column1: A polygon is a 2-dimensional example of the more general polytope in any number of dimensions. There are many more generalizations of polygons defined for different purposes."|2ec16ba8921c982745ebd9e8c7f9e8a0|https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Polygon
19|The word polygon derives from the Greek adjective πολύς (polús) 'much'
column2: 'many' and γωνία (gōnía) 'corner' or 'angle'. It has been suggested that γόνυ (gónu) 'knee' may be the origin of gon.|ee670793527b5d048ec9a18d7af87852|https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Polygon

column1: Polygons are primarily classified by the number of sides.
Polygons may be characterized by their convexity or type of non-convexity:
Convex: any line drawn through the polygon (and not tangent to an edge or corner) meets its boundary exactly twice. As a consequence
column2: all its interior angles are less than 180°. Equivalently
column3: any line segment with endpoints on the boundary passes through only interior points between its endpoints. This condition is true for polygons in any geometry
column4: not just Euclidean.

column1: Non-convex: a line may be found which meets its boundary more than twice. Equivalently
column2: there exists a line segment between two boundary points that passes outside the polygon.

column1: Simple: the boundary of the polygon does not cross itself. All convex polygons are simple.
Concave: Non-convex and simple. There is at least one interior angle greater than 180°.
Star-shaped: the whole interior is visible from at least one point
column2: without crossing any edge. The polygon must be simple
column3: and may be convex or concave. All convex polygons are star-shaped.

column1: Self-intersecting: the boundary of the polygon crosses itself. The term complex is sometimes used in contrast to simple
column2: but this usage risks confusion with the idea of a complex polygon as one which exists in the complex Hilbert plane consisting of two complex dimensions.

column1: Star polygon: a polygon which self-intersects in a regular way. A polygon cannot be both a star and star-shaped.
Equiangular: all corner angles are equal.
Equilateral: all edges are of the same length.
Cyclic: all corners lie on a single circle
Tangential: all sides are tangent to an inscribed circle.
Isogonal or vertex-transitive: all corners lie within the same symmetry orbit. The polygon is also cyclic and equiangular."|be6db54ae4e08e6a41aa444206daa594|https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Polygon
21|"Tangential: all sides are tangent to an inscribed circle.
Isogonal or vertex-transitive: all corners lie within the same symmetry orbit. The polygon is also cyclic and equiangular.

Isotoxal or edge-transitive: all sides lie within the same symmetry orbit. The polygon is also equilateral and tangential.The property of regularity may be defined in other ways: a polygon is regular if and only if it is both isogonal and isotoxal
column2: or equivalently it is both cyclic and equilateral. A non-convex regular polygon is called a regular star polygon.

column1: Rectilinear: the polygon's sides meet at right angles
column2: i.e. all its interior angles are 90 or 270 degrees.

column1: Monotone with respect to a given line L: every line orthogonal to L intersects the polygon not more than twice."|2962aba2a8544331455c0f7be5a4c3a6|https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Polygon

column1: 27|"The idea of a polygon has been generalized in various ways. Some of the more important include:
A spherical polygon is a circuit of arcs of great circles (sides) and vertices on the surface of a sphere. It allows the digon
column2: a polygon having only two sides and two corners
column3: which is impossible in a flat plane. Spherical polygons play an important role in cartography (map making) and in Wythoff's construction of the uniform polyhedra.

column1: A skew polygon does not lie in a flat plane
column2: but zigzags in three (or more) dimensions. The Petrie polygons of the regular polytopes are well known examples.

column1: An apeirogon is an infinite sequence of sides and angles
column2: which is not closed but has no ends because it extends indefinitely in both directions.

column1: A skew apeirogon is an infinite sequence of sides and angles that do not lie in a flat plane.
A polygon with holes is an area-connected or multiply-connected planar polygon with one external boundary and one or more interior boundaries (holes).
A complex polygon is a configuration analogous to an ordinary polygon
column2: which exists in the complex plane of two real and two imaginary dimensions.

column1: An abstract polygon is an algebraic partially ordered set representing the various elements (sides
column3: etc.) and their connectivity. A real geometric polygon is said to be a realization of the associated abstract polygon. Depending on the mapping
column4: all the generalizations described here can be realized.

column1: A polyhedron is a three-dimensional solid bounded by flat polygonal faces
column2: analogous to a polygon in two dimensions. The corresponding shapes in four or higher dimensions are called polytopes. (In other conventions
column3: the words polyhedron and polytope are used in any dimension

69|"Ellipses appear as plane sections of the following quadrics:
If the water's surface is disturbed at one focus of an elliptical water tank
column2: the circular waves of that disturbance
column4: converge simultaneously to a single point: the second focus. This is a consequence of the total travel length being the same along any wall-bouncing path between the two foci.

column2: if a light source is placed at one focus of an elliptic mirror
column3: all light rays on the plane of the ellipse are reflected to the second focus. Since no other smooth curve has such a property
column4: it can be used as an alternative definition of an ellipse. (In the special case of a circle with a source at its center all light would be reflected back to the center.) If the ellipse is rotated along its major axis to produce an ellipsoidal mirror (specifically
column5: a prolate spheroid)
column6: this property holds for all rays out of the source. Alternatively
column7: a cylindrical mirror with elliptical cross-section can be used to focus light from a linear fluorescent lamp along a line of the paper; such mirrors are used in some document scanners."|3637bc6e7d29e840e3d3bb195e09232e|https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ellipse

column1: 71|"Sound waves are reflected in a similar way
column2: so in a large elliptical room a person standing at one focus can hear a person standing at the other focus remarkably well. The effect is even more evident under a vaulted roof shaped as a section of a prolate spheroid. Such a room is called a whisper chamber. The same effect can be demonstrated with two reflectors shaped like the end caps of such a spheroid
column3: placed facing each other at the proper distance. Examples are the National Statuary Hall at the United States Capitol (where John Quincy Adams is said to have used this property for eavesdropping on political matters); the Mormon Tabernacle at Temple Square in Salt Lake City
column4: Utah; at an exhibit on sound at the Museum of Science and Industry in Chicago; in front of the University of Illinois at Urbana–Champaign Foellinger Auditorium; and also at a side chamber of the Palace of Charles V
column5: in the Alhambra.

column2: Johannes Kepler discovered that the orbits along which the planets travel around the Sun are ellipses with the Sun [approximately] at one focus
column3: in his first law of planetary motion. Later
column4: Isaac Newton explained this as a corollary of his law of universal gravitation.

column3: if the two bodies are bound to each other (that is
column4: the total energy is negative)
column5: their orbits are similar ellipses with the common barycenter being one of the foci of each ellipse. The other focus of either ellipse has no known physical significance. The orbit of either body in the reference frame of the other is also an ellipse
column6: with the other body at the same focus."|b2789972a438a25b7d99973a38fddc6c|https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ellipse

column1: 72|"Keplerian elliptical orbits are the result of any radially directed attraction force whose strength is inversely proportional to the square of the distance. Thus
column3: the motion of two oppositely charged particles in empty space would also be an ellipse. (However
column4: this conclusion ignores losses due to electromagnetic radiation and quantum effects
column5: which become significant when the particles are moving at high speed.)

The general solution for a harmonic oscillator in two or more dimensions is also an ellipse. Such is the case
column3: of a long pendulum that is free to move in two dimensions; of a mass attached to a fixed point by a perfectly elastic spring; or of any object that moves under influence of an attractive force that is directly proportional to its distance from a fixed attractor. Unlike Keplerian orbits
column4: however
column5: these ""harmonic orbits"" have the center of attraction at the geometric center of the ellipse
column6: and have fairly simple equations of motion.

column2: the relative phase of two sinusoidal signals can be compared by feeding them to the vertical and horizontal inputs of an oscilloscope. If the Lissajous figure display is an ellipse
column4: the two signals are out of phase.

column1: Two non-circular gears with the same elliptical outline
column2: each pivoting around one focus and positioned at the proper angle
column3: turn smoothly while maintaining contact at all times. Alternatively
column4: they can be connected by a link chain or timing belt
column5: or in the case of a bicycle the main chainring may be elliptical
column6: or an ovoid similar to an ellipse in form. Such elliptical gears may be used in mechanical equipment to produce variable angular speed or torque from a constant rotation of the driving axle
column7: or in the case of a bicycle to allow a varying crank rotation speed with inversely varying mechanical advantage.

column1: Elliptical bicycle gears make it easier for the chain to slide off the cog when changing gears.An example gear application would be a device that winds thread onto a conical bobbin on a spinning machine. The bobbin would need to wind faster when the thread is near the apex than when it is near the base.
In a material that is optically anisotropic (birefringent)
column2: the refractive index depends on the direction of the light. The dependency can be described by an index ellipsoid. (If the material is optically isotropic
elliptical cylinder-shaped reflectors have been used to direct light from the pump lamp (coaxial with one ellipse focal axis) to the active medium rod (coaxial with the second focal axis).

column1: In laser-plasma produced EUV light sources used in microchip lithography
column2: EUV light is generated by plasma positioned in the primary focus of an ellipsoid mirror and is collected in the secondary focus at the input of the lithography machine.

column1: is jointly elliptically distributed if its iso-density contours—loci of equal values of the density function—are ellipses. The concept extends to an arbitrary number of elements of the random vector
column2: in which case in general the iso-density contours are ellipsoids. A special case is the multivariate normal distribution. The elliptical distributions are important in finance because if rates of return on assets are jointly elliptically distributed then all portfolios can be characterized completely by their mean and variance—that is
column3: any two portfolios with identical mean and variance of portfolio return have identical distributions of portfolio return.

column1: Drawing an ellipse as a graphics primitive is common in standard display libraries
column2: such as the MacIntosh QuickDraw API
column3: and Direct2D on Windows. Jack Bresenham at IBM is most famous for the invention of 2D drawing primitives
column4: including line and circle drawing
column5: using only fast integer operations such as addition and branch on carry bit. M. L. V. Pitteway extended Bresenham's algorithm for lines to conics in 1967. Another efficient generalization to draw ellipses was invented in 1984 by Jerry Van Aken.In 1970 Danny Cohen presented at the ""Computer Graphics 1970"" conference in England a linear algorithm for drawing ellipses and circles. In 1971
column6: L. B. Smith published similar algorithms for all conic sections and proved them to have good properties. These algorithms need only a few multiplications and additions to calculate each vector.

column1: It is beneficial to use a parametric formulation in computer graphics because the density of points is greatest where there is the most curvature. Thus
column2: the change in slope between each successive point is small
column3: reducing the apparent ""jaggedness"" of the approximation.

column1: Composite Bézier curves may also be used to draw an ellipse to sufficient accuracy
column2: since any ellipse may be construed as an affine transformation of a circle. The spline methods used to draw a circle may be used to draw an ellipse
column3: since the constituent Bézier curves behave appropriately under such transformations.

column1: It is sometimes useful to find the minimum bounding ellipse on a set of points. The ellipsoid method is quite useful for solving this problem."|4a5637a84ea4e6b3a2e0c931cf275193|https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ellipse
